info.game_comments: First game of Season 24.  New title graphics.

(1, 1).clue: In the 1920s this Fascist leader of Italy set up a puppet regime in Albania & reconquered Libya

(2, 1).clue: Both Hoffman & Streep won Oscars as the title duo in this film

(4, 1).clue: "The Teammates" by David Halberstam chronicles the friendships of Ted Williams & others on this team

(5, 1).clue: In 1850 a St. Louis jury said that this man's prior residence in Wisconsin & Illinois had made him a free man

(6, 1).clue: From the Latin for "having a sharp point", it's an adjective meaning keeping to an arranged time

(1, 2).clue: Elizabeth II succeeded her father, this man who died unexpectedly at age 56

(2, 2).clue: Dustin says, "I was a better man with you, as a woman... than I ever was with a woman, as a man" in this 1982 film

(4, 2).clue: John Grisham switched gears with "Skipping" this holiday, about a couple who want to skip the consumerism

(5, 2).clue: In 1814, while this lawyer & poet was helping to free his friend William Beanes, he saw the bombing of Fort McHenry

(1, 3).clue: On Feb. 8, 1904 Japanese ships attacked this country's fleet at Lushun, Manchuria, beginning a war

(2, 3).clue: Dustin spent more than a weekend as Bernie in this 2004 Stiller & De Niro sequel

(4, 3).clue: "The Devil in the White City" examines "Murder, Magic & Madness" at the 1893 World's Fair in this U.S. city

(5, 3).clue: A skier in his free time, this Mercury 7 astronaut landed his Aurora 7 capsule 250 miles off course in 1962

(6, 3).clue: This "canine" seen here has been known to live in communities of as many as 400 million

(1, 4).clue: On Feb. 15, 1965, Canada's new flag, which prominently featured an 11-pointed one of these, flew for the first time

(2, 4).clue: "Frankly, you're beginning to smell and for a stud in New York, that's a handicap", says Dustin in this 1969 film

(4, 4).clue: In a Stephen King book, writer Paul Sheldon is weary of this title heroine he created

(5, 4).clue: Captured & freed in the War of 1812, he was later an 1852 presidential candidate & a Union general

(6, 4).clue: A large fire built for a funeral cremation

(1, 5).clue: On Valentine's Day 1989 the Ayatollah Khomeini showed no love for this author's "Satanic Verses", giving him a death sentence

(2, 5).clue: Laurence Olivier sets dentistry back about 1,000 years as he works on Dustin in this film; that's not safe at all

(4, 5).clue: Appropriately, Part 3 of this 1953 novel is "Burning Bright"

(5, 5).clue: This White House Press Secretary freed up his schedule in 2006 & was replaced by Tony Snow

(6, 5).clue: In mathematics, it's a flat surface of infinite extent; in carpentry, it's a tool used on surfaces

(1, 1).clue: This country isn't out of "kilt"er with the thistle as its national flower

(2, 1).clue: The "T" in TCM, which shows classic movies, stands for this last name

(4, 1).clue: In the 1980s Kellogg's sugar these were renamed honey these

(5, 1).clue: This period for the earth's moon is 27.322 days

(6, 1).clue: Ingvar Kamprad founded this home-furnishing company in 1943 & once delivered its products by milk van

(1, 2).clue: One March 22, 1994 the Dutch Ambassador to the U.S. gave her a new tulip named for her

(2, 2).clue: This film & arts network has hit the jackpot with reality shows like "Real Housewives of Orange County" & "Project Runway"

(4, 2).clue: They're the waxy cellular structures in which bees store their food & lay their eggs

(5, 2).clue: Photos from Voyager 2 helped spot this moon of Uranus that's named for the heroine of "As You Like It"

(6, 2).clue: This prominent Swedish chemist established the prizes bearing his family name after reading his own obituary in 1888

(1, 3).clue: Singularly speaking, the bright blue cornflower is known as this "button"

(2, 3).clue: "Beach Patrol", "Body of Evidence" & "Forensic Files" are shows on this network

(4, 3).clue: It's also known as winter melon

(5, 3).clue: Saturn's second largest moon, it's named for the mother of the gods

(6, 3).clue: In 1792 Jakob Johan Anckarstrom assassinated the III Swedish king of this name at a masquerade ball

(1, 4).clue: The earliest garden flower to blossom in spring, it still has "snow" in its name

(2, 4).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew "reigns" on the set.)  I'm at the headquarters of this network that was launched to a storm of skepticism, but is celebrating its 25th anniversary in 2007

(3, 4).clue: To persuade by flattery or promises

(4, 4).clue: In a Four Tops hit, this term of endearment follows "sugar pie"

(5, 4).clue: Seen here, they're the bright streaks of lunar ejecta flung from an impact crater

(6, 4).clue: This U.N. Secretary-General died tragically in Africa in 1961

(1, 5).clue: Bloom forms of this large hardy perennial include spoon, quill & pompon

(2, 5).clue: "Dexter" & "Sleeper Cell" are original series on this channel

(4, 5).clue: Aw, shucks!  It's the variety of plant seen here

(5, 5).clue: From the German for rivulet, these trenches on the Moon's surface probably carried lava

(6, 5).clue: This Swedish botanist introduced the binomial system of biological nomenclature now named for him

(0, 0).clue: In 1949 he wrote, "If you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face--forever"
